summary_markdown:
# About Quartet Health

Quartet Health is a tech-enabled behavioral health company founded in 2014. The company focuses on delivering integrated mental health care through partnerships with health plans, systems, and provider groups. Quartet Health aims to improve access to quality behavioral health services by leveraging sophisticated data analytics and personalized care solutions [(Source)](https://leadiq.com/c/quartet-health/5a1d98992300005200874388).

Quartet Health operates in 39 states and partners with health plans, health systems, and community mental health centers to provide comprehensive behavioral health solutions [(Quartet Health on 2024-09-20)](https://www.quartethealth.com/). The company serves a diverse clientele, including health plans, health systems, and community mental health centers, aiming to improve access to mental health care for all individuals [(Quartet Health on 2020-05-27)](https://www.quartethealth.com/health-systems/).

The company has raised at least $219.5 million in venture capital funding from notable investors, including Oak HC/FT, GV (formerly Google Ventures), and Centene Corporation [(Source)](https://leadiq.com/c/quartet-health/5a1d98992300005200874388). While specific revenue figures are not publicly disclosed, Quartet Health has demonstrated significant growth, particularly following its acquisition of InnovaTel Telepsychiatry and the launch of its Whole Health program [(MobiHealthNews, 2024-03-20)](https://www.mobihealthnews.com/news/clover-health-quartet-launch-whole-health-program-address-mental-illness-seniors).

Quartet Health's primary product offering is its Whole Health program, which combines in-person and virtual therapy, psychiatry, and self-guided programs. The service matches patients with mental health professionals based on their preferences and needs, utilizing the Clover Assistant platform to enhance care coordination [(MobiHealthNews, 2024-03-20)](https://www.mobihealthnews.com/news/clover-health-quartet-launch-whole-health-program-address-mental-illness-seniors).

The company emphasizes a culture of diversity, equity, and inclusion (DEI) and prioritizes the security of patient data, adhering to HIPAA and other regulatory standards [(Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion at Quartet on 2021-10-18)](https://www.quartethealth.com/dei/) [(Quartet Health on 2021-08-06)](https://www.quartethealth.com/security/).

# Key Personnel

- **Christina Mainelli**: CEO of Quartet Health. She has emphasized the importance of addressing the fragmented healthcare system that patients with serious mental illnesses (SMI) often navigate [(Quartet Health, 2024-03-19)](https://www.quartethealth.com/perspectives/quartet-health-launches-innovative-whole-health-program-to-improve-outcomes-for-patients-with-serious-mental-illness/).
- **Dr. Michael J. Lipp**: Chief Medical Officer. He has highlighted the need for coordinated care for patients with SMI, noting that many do not see a primary care physician or a behavioral health provider [(Quartet Health, 2024-03-19)](https://www.quartethealth.com/perspectives/quartet-health-launches-innovative-whole-health-program-to-improve-outcomes-for-patients-with-serious-mental-illness/).

# News

## Recent Developments

### Whole Health Program Launch
In March 2024, Quartet Health launched its Whole Health program in partnership with Clover Health, targeting patients with serious mental illnesses (SMI). This program is designed to provide comprehensive care that integrates physical, behavioral, and social health services, addressing the needs of a traditionally underserved population [(MobiHealthNews, 2024-03-20)](https://www.mobihealthnews.com/news/clover-health-quartet-launch-whole-health-program-address-mental-illness-seniors). The Whole Health program is the first fully integrated model of its kind, taking accountability for the total cost of care (TCOC) for complex members [(Quartet Health, 2024-03-19)](https://www.quartethealth.com/perspectives/quartet-health-launches-innovative-whole-health-program-to-improve-outcomes-for-patients-with-serious-mental-illness/).

### Acquisition of InnovaTel Telepsychiatry
In December 2021, Quartet Health acquired InnovaTel Telepsychiatry, expanding its capacity to deliver virtual mental health services and enhancing its patient identification tools [(MobiHealthNews, 2024-03-20)](https://www.mobihealthnews.com/news/clover-health-quartet-launch-whole-health-program-address-mental-illness-seniors).

## Market Position and Scale
Quartet Health operates in over 30 markets and employs more than 250 behavioral health clinicians, serving approximately 500,000 patients annually. The company connects to over 10,000 behavioral health providers, reaching up to 21 million patients [(A Whole-Person Approach to Mental Health, 2024-04-08)](https://insights.som.yale.edu/insights/whole-person-approach-to-mental-health). The Whole Health program is currently being piloted in the New Jersey market, with plans for expansion based on its success [(Quartet Health, 2024-03-19)](https://www.quartethealth.com/perspectives/quartet-health-launches-innovative-whole-health-program-to-improve-outcomes-for-patients-with-serious-mental-illness/).

## Financial Performance
Quartet Health's focus on value-based care is expected to enhance financial sustainability by aligning incentives with improved patient outcomes [(MobiHealthNews, 2024-03-20)](https://www.mobihealthnews.com/news/clover-health-quartet-launch-whole-health-program-address-mental-illness-seniors).

## Conclusion
Quartet Health is positioned as a leader in the behavioral health space, particularly with its innovative Whole Health program aimed at addressing the needs of patients with serious mental illnesses. The company's strategic partnerships, focus on integrated care, and commitment to improving access and outcomes for underserved populations make it an attractive option for prospective candidates and investors. As the demand for mental health services continues to grow, Quartet Health's approach to value-based care and holistic treatment models may provide a competitive advantage in the evolving healthcare landscape.

# Quartet Health Summary

## Company Overview
Quartet Health is a leading value-based behavioral healthcare company focused on expanding access to high-quality care for individuals with behavioral health needs, including serious mental illness. The company operates in 39 states and partners with health plans, health systems, and community mental health centers to provide comprehensive behavioral health solutions [(Quartet Health on 2024-09-20)](https://www.quartethealth.com/).

## History and Leadership
Quartet Health was founded with the mission to improve lives through quality, whole-person care. Puneet Singh serves as the CEO, bringing extensive experience from his previous roles, including Chief Growth Officer at Anthem and private equity investor. His background in healthcare and corporate strategy positions him well to lead Quartet in its mission [(Quartet Health on 2020-05-27)](https://www.quartethealth.com/about-us/).

## Services and Products
Quartet Health offers a range of services designed to connect individuals with the mental health care they need. These include:

- **Therapy**: Individual sessions with therapists to address various mental health issues.
- **Psychiatry**: Medical treatment for mental health conditions, including medication management.
- **Digital Options**: Online programs that provide tools for managing mental health symptoms, accessible via phone or computer [(What Kind of Mental Health Care Options Can I Access Through Quartet? on 2020-10-08)](https://www.quartethealth.com/resources/care-options/).

## Customer Base
Quartet Health serves a diverse clientele, including health plans, health systems, and community mental health centers. They aim to improve access to mental health care for all individuals, ensuring that care is tailored to meet the specific needs of patients [(Quartet Health on 2020-05-27)](https://www.quartethealth.com/health-systems/).

## Culture and Values
Quartet Health emphasizes a culture of diversity, equity, and inclusion (DEI). The company fosters a supportive environment through employee resource groups and aims to build products that prioritize health equity, ensuring that all patients can access the best mental health care available [(Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion at Quartet on 2021-10-18)](https://www.quartethealth.com/dei/).

## Security and Privacy
Quartet Health prioritizes the security of patient data, adhering to HIPAA and other regulatory standards. They utilize Amazon Web Services (AWS) for secure data storage and processing, ensuring that sensitive information is protected [(Quartet Health on 2021-08-06)](https://www.quartethealth.com/security/).

## Conclusion
Quartet Health is dedicated to transforming the behavioral healthcare landscape by providing innovative, accessible, and high-quality care solutions. Their commitment to DEI, patient security, and comprehensive service offerings positions them as a trusted partner in the mental health space.

# [Quartet Health on 2024-09-20](https://www.quartethealth.com/)
Quartet Health is an industry-leading value-based behavioral healthcare company. We expand access to and deliver high-quality care for people with behavioral health needs, including serious mental illness. Quartet’s care enablement and delivery offerings seek to improve the lives of patients by providing whole, human, behavioral health care to those in need.

Our innovative approaches to navigating the complex mental health landscape enable us to identify, engage, and care for patients and deliver an end-to-end behavioral health solution. We are a trusted partner of health plans, health systems, and community mental health centers that serve patients in 39 states across the country.

# [Quartet Health on 2021-08-06](https://www.quartethealth.com/security/)
At Quartet, we recognize the highly sensitive nature of data entrusted to us by our partners. We also recognize the regulatory requirements set forth by HIPAA / HITECH and industry best practices and standards (e.g., AICPA Trust Services Principles and ISO27001/ 2) and strive to meet and exceed those requirements. The goal of this Security Statement is to ensure transparency regarding our security practices, and to help reassure you that your data is appropriately protected.

You may report security issues to us at [email protected]

Quartet utilizes Amazon Web Services (“AWS”) in order to take advantage of the elasticity, reliability and security of the AWS Infrastructure as a cloud service.

All data is stored and processed through AWS’ certified-secure facilities:

AWS hosting facilities are SOC Type 1 & 2 certified and certified to meet ISO standards

AWS hosting facilities accessible only by biometric scanning

24/ 7 monitoring by security guards

24/ 7 video surveillance

# [Quartet Health on 2020-08-27](https://www.quartethealth.com/privacy-policy/)
As described in this Privacy Policy, we may collect certain personal information from or about you in connection with your use of, or your acceptance of, the Services. Personal information, for purposes of this Privacy Policy, generally includes information that may be used to identify you. The types of personal information we collect about you will depend on your relationship with Quartet. You are not required to provide all personal information identified in this Privacy Policy; however, please be advised that if you do not provide the personal information requested by us, including personal information necessary to respond to customer inquiries, we may be unable to provide some or all of the Services to you. In some cases, and if applicable, we may request additional consent from users if we think there is other information that will improve our ability to coordinate care or tailor our services to the needs of our users.

Marketing and informational communications.

If you have provided your contact information to us, we may store and use that information to contact you for marketing and promotional purposes by various means, including regular mail, email, telephone, voicemail, or SMS (text message). Users may receive messages about appointment reminders, general health care information and wellness programs sponsored by Quartet. You can recognize when an affiliated business is associated with our services, and we will only disclose your Personal Information with that affiliated business to the extent that it is necessary for the delivery of the transaction or service.

We may receive a confirmation when you open an email from us. This confirmation helps us make our communications with you more interesting and improve our services. To the extent permitted by law, and if you have provided your contact information to us, we may store and use that information to contact you about the coordination of your care by various means, including regular mail, email, or telephone, including voicemail or SMS (text message). To the extent you voluntarily opt to have SMS notifications sent directly to your mobile phone, we receive and store the information you provide, including your telephone number. You can adjust the types of notifications you receive and when you receive them by editing your SMS notification settings. We may also use your information to notify you about appointments and/or to communicate with you about your Account. You will have the ability to opt out of any marketing or advertising communications, but we may still send you communications relating to your Account for purposes important to the Services, such as password recovery.

We do not rent or sell your personal information. We may disclose your personal information with third parties as described in this section.

We may de-identify Personal Information so that a user is not identified as an individual, and provide that information to our partners. We may also provide aggregate usage information to our partners (or allow partners to collect that information from our users), who may use such information to understand how often and in what ways people use our Services, so that they, too, can provide an optimal online experience.

We will retain a user’s information for as long as the Account is active or as needed to provide our services to the user, in accordance with applicable law. Notwithstanding any provision to the contrary, we will retain, access, use and disclose information as we believe is necessary to comply with our legal obligations, resolve disputes, enforce our Terms of Use and other agreements, or to protect the rights, property or safety of Quartet, our employees, our users or others.

The Website’s use cookies and similar technologies to improve user experience, for performance and analytics, and to improve our content, products, and services.

A “cookie” is a small text file that a web server stores in browser software. A browser sends cookies to a server when the browser makes a connection to the server (for example, when requesting a web page from the same domain that created the cookie). The purpose of cookies is to remember the browser over time and distinguish one browser instance (or user) from all others. Some cookies and other technologies may serve to track personal information previously entered by a web user on the Website. Most browsers allow you to control cookies, including whether or not to accept them and how to remove them. Cookies can remember login information, preferences, and similar information.

Cookies, as well as other tracking technologies, such as HTML5 local storage, and Local Shared Objects (such as “Flash” cookies), and similar mechanisms, may record information such as a unique identifier, information you enter in a form, IP address, and other categories of data. We may also use web beacons or “pixels,” and in certain circumstances may collect IP address, screen resolution and browser software and operating system types, clickstream patterns, dates and times that our site is accessed, and other categories of data.

If you want to block the use and saving of cookies from the Website on to the computer’s or other electronic device’s hard drive, you should take the necessary steps within your web browser’s settings to block all cookies from the Website and external serving vendors, or use the cookie control system, if available upon first visit, which is available here. Please note that if you choose to erase or block your cookies, certain parts of our Website may not function correctly. For information on how to disable cookies, refer to your browser’s documentation.

We may also use what is known as “client-side page tagging,” which uses code on each page to write certain information about the page and the visitor to a log when a page is rendered by your web browser. This technique is also commonly used on commercial websites. “Tagging” does result in a JavaScript program running on your computer, but it is limited to providing information about the page that you are requesting and the configuration of your browser. It will not read any of your data files, or execute any additional programs. It does not extract any personal information about you, such as your name or address. You can prevent tagging by disabling JavaScript in your browser, but that may prevent you from using all of our Website’s functions.

Quartet may change this Privacy Policy from time to time. When material updates are made, the Privacy Policy version date will also be updated to reflect that a revision occurred, and we will alert you to changes by placing a notice on www.quartethealth.com, by sending you an email, and/or by some other means. We encourage you to periodically reread this Privacy Policy to see if there have been any changes that may affect you. A user is bound by any changes to the Privacy Policy when using the Website or Services after such changes have been first posted. This Privacy Policy is not intended to and does not create any contractual or other legal rights in or on behalf of any party.

# [Quartet Health on 2020-05-27](https://www.quartethealth.com/about-us/)
Puneet Singh serves as CEO of Quartet Health. Prior to joining Quartet, Puneet was the Chief Growth Officer for the Diversified Business Group at Anthem, where he was responsible for the external growth of the division, including AIM, Aspire, Beacon Health Options, CareMore, HealthGuide, and other businesses. He joined Anthem through the acquisition of Aspire Health, where he served as Chief Development Officer and helped grow the business from a startup to the nation’s largest provider of community-based palliative care.

Earlier in his career, Puneet was a private equity investor and also served as a Vice President at Accretive Health, where he led corporate strategy, marketing, and communications for the company. Puneet began his healthcare career as an investment banker at Goldman Sachs, where he worked on a range of M&A and capital markets transactions in the healthcare industry.

He is a graduate of the Wharton School at the University of Pennsylvania.

# [Progress Update Guidelines on 2021-01-06](https://www.quartethealth.com/progress-update-guidelines/)
Patient progress updates: guidelines and examples

Quartet’s Care Team Experience (CTE) enables primary care physicians and mental health providers to collaborate on a patient’s treatment plan. Due to the sensitivity of the information, this memo addresses what type of communication is appropriate between providers.

The HIPAA Privacy Rule and certain state and Federal rules (collectively, “Privacy Rules”) establish standards to protect patient health information. Pursuant to these Privacy Rules, certain information, which receive special protections, should not be shared in communications facilitated by the Care Team Experience, including: psychotherapy notes, substance abuse records, and HIV/AIDS-related information.

Psychotherapy notes are recorded by a mental health provider documenting or analyzing the contents of a conversation during a confidential individual, group, joint, or family session. Quartet does not permit such notes to be communicated in order to protect your patient’s privacy.

Substance abuse records from “Part 2” federally assisted treatment programs require an additional level of consent for disclosure and Quartet is not responsible for obtaining the requisite consent from clients. Quartet does not permit such records to be disclosed in order to protect your patients’ privacy if you are a Part 2 Program, unless you have obtained appropriate consent. If you are not a Part 2 Program, you may use your discretion in sharing this information.

HIV/AIDS-related information is often protected under state law and Quartet does not permit this information to be disclosed in order to protect your patient’s privacy.

Below are guidelines and examples to follow when engaging in collaborative care.

Guidelines for sharing patient information through Quartet

Progress updates help clinicians and mental health professionals approach their patient’s care by giving each perspective on the patient’s total health.

Initial progress update

Diagnosis

Treatment plan (modalities, recommended frequency, medication)

Alerts (engagement/compliance, functional status and motivation)

Ongoing progress updates

# [What Kind of Mental Health Care Options Can I Access Through Quartet? on 2020-10-08](https://www.quartethealth.com/resources/care-options/)
At Quartet, our vision is that one day, every person with a mental health condition will get the care they need. No one’s experience with mental health is the same – different people have different needs, not just clinically, but in terms of access, too.

Getting people the mental health care they need calls for a range of mental health care options. Below, you can learn more about the care options* available through Quartet.

Therapy

A therapist helps you to talk through your thoughts and feelings. This may be related to handling difficult experiences, solving problems, changing behavior or learning how to manage stress.

Therapy sessions are usually offered weekly for 45-60 minutes, and can either be in-person or virtual. Virtual sessions can be over the phone or video conferencing. How long you choose to attend therapy will vary depending on your individual needs and goals.

Psychiatry

A psychiatrist is a doctor who is trained and specializes in treating mental health conditions using medication. Psychiatrists will talk through your symptoms, create a treatment plan, explain medication options, and keep track of your progress.

Psychiatry appointments may be in-person or virtual, depending on the patient. Virtual sessions can be over the phone or video conferencing. First appointments may be between 45-60 minutes and follow up appointments are shorter and less frequent. Many people who see a psychiatrist also see a therapist.

Digital Options

Online programs allow you to access care wherever you are, at your convenience and help you manage symptoms like stress, anxiety, or sadness using tools that help you change behaviors and improve your outlook. These programs are goal-oriented and can be done on your own or with the support of an optional coach. Online programs are often accessible by phone, computer or tablet.

*The mental health care options available to you will depend on your clinical needs, preferences, and insurance. Policies regarding in-person or virtual care are subject to change, and it is recommended that you verify coverage with your insurance plan.

reviews.cons: Lots to learn. Multiple interlocking systems, lots of knowledge. Broad responsibilities. Good if you are easily bored.
reviews.pros: Good company. They care about their employees. What they do helps the world. Good pay and benefits. Unlimited PTO you can actually use. Great diversity.

reviews.advice: Offer coaching to all associates in C-suite, Senior Leadership, and in Executive Support to better align messaging and execution, as well as to provide cohesive understanding of business etiquette.
reviews.cons:
- There are some associates who do not pull their weight in comparison to others (same as everywhere).
 - There are a handful of developing leaders who do not credit contributors as they should, which causes occasional resentment.
 - The business is constantly changing, resulting in burnout for some associates.
reviews.pros:
- The vast majority of people working at Quartet Health are friendly, kind, and extremely hard-working. 
 - Leadership is dedicated to growing a successful company while improving the lives of the people in the Behavioral Health population. 
 - The salaries/benefits are competitive.
 - The teamwork in my area is probably the strongest and most supportive of any company I have ever worked at during my career.

reviews.advice: Not worth wasting the words. They don't care. This will be explained as just another "disgruntled former employee."
reviews.cons:
EVERYTHING else.
No co culture. Killed when they ousted the former CEO. ERGs are defunct - they laid off everyone involved over the course of two years. No one cares enough about the company or culture to try.
Management decreases benefits about every 6 months. Raises are paltry. Everything from company holidays to vacation time constantly stripped back for non-leadership employees. Ask someone about the Juneteenth or maternity leave debates. It will tell you everything you need to know.
Continue to claim "start up" status only because they are floundering for a strategy they can monetize. Total lack a consistent roadmap, because the strategy is changes yearly. 
Ever-increasing workload shoveled on the few employees not laid off with no increase in compensation or titles. Employee stratification undervalues everyone except leadership. Use that that to refuse to compensate employees for the additional work demanded of them.
Commitment to DEI is a lie, especially at the leadership level. All management hiring based on knowing the existing management team. Very white, hetero, male. Don't let the current female CEO fool you.
HR team tries, but they are handcuffed by leadership. As long as an employee is "producing" or part of the leadership circle, bad behavior is excused. Repeat offenders sit on the leadership team, and the people that reported leave rather than fight a losing battle. 
If you want real nightmares, know they laid off people on maternity/paternity leave, and laid off an employee that was literally weeks from her due date. That is the leadership you're getting here.
reviews.pros: Coworkers are some of the best. Dedicated to the mental health of their users.
reviews.summary: The bad reviews are real, no matter what management says

reviews.cons: Virtual-first working style isn't for everyone, but HR and leadership continue to find ways to foster a strong sense of community. There are regional meet-ups and budget for team building activities.
reviews.pros:
Quartet Health has a very mission & purpose-driven culture. The people who work here are passionate about improving access to quality healthcare for everyone. Each monthly all-employee Town Hall meeting starts with a Patient story to highlight the impact we're making in people's lives. Instances where employees demonstrate our Corporate values are also recognized each meeting.

There has been strong continuity among senior leadership the last few years and they have cast a compelling vision of the future to strengthen alignment at all levels on the pathway forward.
reviews.summary: Great place to make an impact in the communities we serve & grow your career

reviews.advice: Keep up the great work! Continue to listen, be responsive, and value employees, clients, and patients as Quartet continues to grow. Staying flexible to respond to market needs and opportunities will ensure we remain successful.
reviews.cons: Honestly, I can't think of any major downsides to working at Quartet Health.
reviews.pros: Quartet Health is a fantastic place to work, and I get to work with a wonderful group of talented people. My direct leader creates a supportive environment, offering plenty of opportunities for continuous learning and growth, which makes me feel truly valued. The work we do here has a real impact, and it's incredibly rewarding to see the difference we make. Additionally, the senior and executive leadership genuinely listens to us, which is a rare and appreciated quality.
reviews.summary: A Great Place to Work with Amazing People

reviews.cons: -The only major con of working here has been some of the uncertainty with lay-offs last year... However, the whole industry experienced similar things, and Quartet has adapted well and is moving forward leaner and stronger than ever, allowing for more runway to "make it." And it seems we finally have the right people on board.
reviews.pros:
-A lot of smart and dedicated people work here. However, the culture is not overly stuffy and there is no air of pretentiousness like at some start-ups / growth stage companies
-The mission of expanding access to quality mental healthcare is at the core of the business and most of the employees care greatly about this
-The work is interesting, as there are multiple product lines and plenty of analytically interesting challenges to overcome, as with any business striving for maturation and sustainable profitability
-The business is fully remote, and work-life balance is good. Even in busy times with long hours for a period of time, the flexibility of being remote to take breaks during the day and get things done later makes it bearable long-term
reviews.summary: Good People, Great Mission, Interesting Work

reviews.cons: No L&D or benefits for learning,
reviews.pros: Committed leadership, good people overall

reviews.cons: Change can stress folks out. Its personally not a con for me but I know for others rapid change is difficult.
reviews.pros: The team is great in total. Whether its your direct team or working crossfunctionally, everyone is generally pleasant to work with. Its very flexible, everyone is understanding of work/life balance. Leadership is sharp.

reviews.cons: Frequent management change and reorgs
reviews.pros: Lot of opportunities to grow

reviews.cons:
-No raise or cost of living adjustment in 2 years
-Do not know how to value employees.
-"Start up culture" (roll out new initiatives, not the best communication, focus on growth-but not on retention)
-Christmas Bonus was a certificate valued up to $20 to a website (options included 1 of the following: a pair of socks, a wick trimmer, wool dryer balls, a bar of fancy chocolate, a few tea bags, a 'boutique' car air freshener, and a few other miscellaneous items)
reviews.pros:
-Meaningful work
-Clinical leadership is solid

reviews.advice: For those that care, your best option is to leave and find new opportunities. This ship sank and is still sitting at the harbor. There is no true north and it is too late to course correct. For those that think this is a cash cow, keep up the good work-you will be the last ones standing.
reviews.cons:
-poor work life balance
-untrustworthy leadership (blatant lies)
-terrible compensation and benefits (unlimited PTO is not a benefit)
-toxic work culture (leaders belittle colleagues on team calls and then slack on the side apologizing)
-micromanagement and no upward mobility
-VERY little diversity on leadership bench....
reviews.pros: There are no pros, we have lied about getting patients to care, we have lied to our customers (IBC, BCNC, Horizon). The only people that join this company are former employees from Aspire. The culture has tanked into a bottomless pit of toxicity. The new leadership blames the old, they hire too many "executives" and no doers. The CEO is smart but surrounded himself with very greedy leaders and made some very poor choices in human resources.
reviews.summary: Bottomless pit of toxicity and ineffective leaders

reviews.advice:
It's a classic case of not taking care of your employees. Leadership has no idea what employees do and how they speak/assist patients all day every day. It is incredibly taxing work. 

Employees talk amongst themselves and morale is incredibly low. Never worked at a place with such low morale as here. They talk about quitting, burnout, and dread of coming into work every day. 

Implement real changes like higher salaries, less micro management, better work life balance, and adjusted metrics. 

The work Quartet does is important but the culture and environment isn't helpful to the mission. 

Bad employee experience = bad patient experience. Quite obvious but this seems like a concept that hasn't yet been realized by leadership.
reviews.cons:
- There's a lot of micro management because they are so focused on metrics. It creates extreme burnout, stress, and overall just a horrible time while at work. The metrics goals are not sustainable and unreachable. 

- The salary is laughable. For the type and amount of work that is required, they do not pay well. People make a lot more doing a lot less elsewhere. 

-The bonuses are also laughable. Almost impossible to attain because it's based on unrealistic goals. You have to work like a robot and still you may not reach them. Yet they wonder why no one's metrics are met. 

- Turnover rate is incredibly high. Management changes, poorly thought out metrics and workflows, and a lot of the jobs themselves are horrible to do. Always understaffed due to high turnover. 

- Out of Touch Leadership: Great lip service but that's about it. Employees are miserable yet leadership thinks everything is great. For Employee Appreciation Day, let's just say their show of appreciation became a running joke in the company.
reviews.pros:
Pros:
The coworkers are some of the nicest, well intentioned, true advocates of mental health you'll ever meet. 

Benefits are okay. Health plans are decent and they reimburse a lot of expenses. 

Pretty much it.
reviews.summary: Nice People but Horrible Expectations and Pay

reviews.advice: Complete overhaul of the culture.
reviews.cons: Everything is horrendous at Quartet
reviews.pros: Run! Do not work there. Management does not care about your well being.

reviews.cons: too much focus on brand over substance & products
reviews.pros: Fast paced environment; opportunities for growth and development.

reviews.advice: Promote from within and give people opportunities to grow. Listen to people with clinical backgrounds, and not just the clinical people from Innovatel. You don't even recognize the talent and knowledge that has been at Quartet for years because you don't ask, and that is a shame.
reviews.cons:
-More than anything, the biggest con is that leadership does not accept feedback. They are very defensive when faced with it, and I have heard many in the C suite laugh at how people at Quartet are "too sensitive" or "get offended by everything." They blame people for being unhappy and insist that's why the culture is bad.
-Decision makers do not have enough of a clinical background or lens to be successful in this type of company. When trying to figure out why patients aren't getting to care, they ignore the real reasons because they just want the quick fixes. They don't want to invest in fixing the tech or in making a positive experience for patients or providers. They just want to find the easiest, fastest thing they can present as a "solution" to investors and customers
-Leaders say to follow the data, but when presented with data that contradicts what they want to hear, the response is "Are you sure that's what it says? Let's pull it differently" until it aligns with their expectations.

It makes sense why leadership had to change and why Quartet focuses on just getting acquired. But they are so incredibly top heavy and filled with middle managers that I don't feel confident the company will reach that goal. They prioritize hiring old coworkers from Aspire to fill leadership roles, which is not only frustrating from a nepotism standpoint but it also means no opportunities for advancement for people who have been with the company and want to actually grow in their career. 

Unless you are coming from their white boys club in Nashville, I would not recommend joining at this time. Most of us are only still here while we actively look for other jobs.
reviews.pros:
-Some good people still at the company. If they are allowed to have their ideas heard and executed on, I think Quartet could pull off an acquisition. Also culturally there are some fun, smart people who are enjoyable to work alongside.
-Work/life balance can be really positive because expectations are low
-The mission is great
-Unlimited PTO
reviews.summary: New Strategy is Quantity over Quality

reviews.advice: Change doesn't happen in a day, but stay focused on what we commit to (to our team and our clients). Changing strategy is not always translated well to people's day to day, or thought through at that level. I agree with some of the other reviews that more questions should be asked of those actually doing the work prior to major changes.
reviews.cons:
- Like others said, Quartet recently hired groups of people from Aspire and similar places. I agree we should expand our horizons to keep adding diverse talent
-The 401(k) match should be increased
- Some of the leaders (high level, the managers are usually great) are better than others. My advice is to ask thoughtful questions about your executive leadership when interviewing here

None of these are dealbreakers for me, so I'm keeping my rating at 5 stars, but realistically it's probably between 4-5 stars based on some of the cons.
reviews.pros:
Quartet is one of many players in the health tech-enabled space. It's not for everyone, but I think it has a lot going for it. My experience at Quartet has had quite a few "pros."

- Smart and kind people across the board. Feeling like you can reach out to anyone with a question is paid lip service at other companies, but it's real here
- Inspiring mission, evolving strategy. Shifting strategy is frustrating, but the new strategy is objectively clearer, and I understand how we plan to make money with the new changes. Before...not so much 
- New, interesting challenges. This probably isn't true for every role or team, but I think my day-to-day is rich with new experiences
- I'm not patient-facing, so my view is limited, but I think we highlight our patient wins well and often. I love hearing about the indirect impact of my work on someone getting the care they need

I feel like you could throw a stone and hit 10 other companies "similar" to Quartet (Cerebral, Ginger, Alma, etc). I like what we're doing differently, the people, and my work, so it's a great match for me. Maybe it's not for you, but I'd take other reviews with a grain of salt and find out for yourself.
reviews.summary: Lots of change, but lots of positives as well

reviews.cons: I was brought in as a temp with the hopes of converting to perm, but at the time of my short-lived employment I soon came to find that the platform that the ops team and management was working on had unrealistic expectations of turnover time between calls with patients. It's been a handful of years since so I do not not how it's operating currently, but management certainly did not take this pain point seriously as my counterparts were already familiar with the inner workings of the platform. I was coming in brand new trying to adjust to everything and was ultimately let go because I could not keep my head above the water (unrealistic way of getting through the patient call logs and turnaround time). Poorly mismanaged then and certainly paid undermarket. Was a blessing in disguise to be let go.
reviews.pros: none I can think of.

reviews.cons: No pay transparency within company. Lack of communication from higher up
reviews.pros: Good benefits, wonderful coworkers, good hours

reviews.advice: It feels like the company has lost its drive and its sense of purpose. The employees no longer feel inspired since David left as CEO.
reviews.cons: 401K matching is a joke; the mission of the organization changes constantly; the culture is non-existent at this point (early 2022)
reviews.pros: Have generally enjoyed working my coworkers; have been fortunate to have a very caring manager who wishes to see us succeed personally and professionally; mostly good benefits

reviews.advice:
You didn't listen to us before, I doubt you will now. But let's start with less LinkedIn posts about vulnerable, service leadership styles that contradict closed door behavior. 

Everything I had to say was shared over the years and in my exit interview. The phrase I heard was "Yep, we're aware and heard it." So it's nothing new, it's something chronic that just won't go away until Quartet does.
reviews.cons:
Okay now that we've covered the positives of what you can learn, let's talk about the cons at the center of this charred ball of meat.

In a single bite it comes down to no accountability for business failures, inappropriate workplace behavior, and the complete inability to accept feedback water falling all the way from the top. Let's break this down for the palate, shall we?

Look, accountability is difficult for the ego. You have to chew through and acknowledge the mistake, the oversight, the lack of research, the lack of innovation, the repeating of mistakes and failed initiatives, the willful neglect of user feedback, the pushing out of subject matter experts, the nepotism, the rapid career acceleration of friends over qualified candidates, the lack of communication, the close door decision making that lead to layoffs and a company reorg that had people taken from roles they were exceedingly well qualified for and putting them into ones that were in totally different fields, the lack meaningful feedback loops, the redefining of KPIs every quartet to spin a success story, the...oh...yeah there is a lot to chew through here. 

Hmmm, I guess we can just say that accountability starts at the top and in my 5 years I saw its presence dwindle into non-existence. Don't worry though, they'll send out a survey to learn more about why surveys don't lead to impactful changes.

The inappropriate behavior is hard to break down here, so I'll simply say that I took my fiancée to one work event, never again. Need to say more? No I do not.

Feedback is more a confirmation bias loop and if you're not part of the inner circle you will be stone walled from any meaningful platform to share concerns and it'll stunt your career progress. At Quartet who you know matters more than performance or competence.

There's a lot more complexity to the soup, huh? I hope by now you've spat it out, complained to the waiter, asked to see the manager, and know with conviction this ain't the place to dine. You can read from other reviewers, but be warned the current staff like to write their own and claim they have world famous matzoballs. I am not sure the health department would even consider it human food....and do you really want to find out for yourself when this market is exploding with new health tech companies and there are several, attractive competitors to consider?
reviews.pros:
Quartet is a weird soup. 

You may be exposed to many career pathways and find nuggets of insight about the healthcare ecosystem and tech. You can nibble into some great skill development areas and have freedom to laterally change teams, if you have a supportive manager. However, this will be marred by dysfunctional processes, broken departments, defeated colleagues, an incoherent and always changing business strategy, and an inner circle that makes life miserable for everyone in their wake. 

Everything you could learn at Quartet can be found in "The Hard Thing About Hard Things" or "Why the Mighty Fall". Go to your local book store and check out books on failed leadership, iteration, innovation, and accountability. You'll come out learning everything you would have gleaned here while enjoying life at a functional start-up building your professional equity in a meaningful way.

Don't get swayed by the seasoning of "this is a difficult problem we're trying to solve" or the spices of "we've learned a lot along the way". As a five year vet at Quartet what they learned was how to reuse the same talk track after every failure. 

The mission meant the world to me as someone who lost loved ones to suicide, addiction, and domestic violence. Quartet will exploit your goodwill and dedication to pawn a quick buck on a doomed to fail business model. Trust me, this soup is served to burn your mouth and make you numb to sensation so you just trust them when they say "This is good soup". It ain't!

reviews.advice: Treat your employees like you use to. Most of the great talent has left or is going to leave. Why be the Walmart of digital health when you could be Target.
reviews.cons: In my time with the company they have slowly chipped away at the benefits package they offered. When I first started unlimited PTO was standard along with other great benefits. We recently have been told that we will no longer be receiving such a benefit. Along with that they have changed us from a salaried position to hourly. It is in my opinion that Quartet no longer cares about the employees who do the brunt of the work and are more about the bottom line. I’d think twice before apply here.

- Mission Driven

reviews.cons: It's not a good place for you if you can't adapt to change.

reviews.cons: The con is also a pro in being remote. Its nice to work from home but you only get virtual interactions

reviews.advice: None! Continue working to promote transparency and a culture of One Team!

reviews.pros:
The company is very mission driven and you can feel that in every interaction. 
One of our core values is that we are One Team and you can truly feel that when working cross-functionally. 
Leadership has done an amazing job at taking previous feedback and implementing it to make them more available to employees by creating monthly office hours where employees can learn about what the strategy for that department looks like. 

In my 10+ years in the corporate world I can truly say that Quartet has been the best company I've ever worked for. I have never felt more valued in a corporate setting as I do at Quartet.

reviews.cons: Limited room for growth Benefits that are not aligned with rest of the company.
reviews.pros: Nice coworkers, remote work environment

reviews.advice: Take a hard look at who you surround yourself with and see if they are truly contributing to the mission. Or do they just create meetings and a facade and blame others for failing to meet unattainable goals.
reviews.cons:
- You get $60 Million to buy a care delivery company, but can't support existing team members with much needed support (aka no backfilling any of the amazing people who have left)
- VERY TOP HEAVY organization that brought in so many leaders, so much duplicative "strategy" with no one to do the hard work
- Leadership is mysogoniatic, NO DEI initiatives (even though there is an amazing DEI Director) it's all a facade, she can't get any iniative moving because leadership shuts her down
-They ironically don't care about your burn out or mental health and with the bummer of people leaving, they don't have direction or strategy on how to operate with reduced headcount, they just assume the reduced number of people can do the same amount of work, but dont see (or care, because they were constantly told) that the structure was not sustainable
reviews.pros:

-The COO is an amazing woman, but when announced as COO seemed surprise at her title, which concerned me

reviews.cons: Management is mostly from traditional/large companies. Startup culture is slowly fading. Hiring for non-clinical roles has dried up.
reviews.pros: Has been an exciting place to work since its acquisition last year of Innovatel. Lots of new opportunities and initiatives that feel like we're heading in the right directions. Culture is very strongly positive.

reviews.cons: Quartet is struggling to find product market fit. Some of its products are useful and impactful , some are a solution in search of a problem.
reviews.pros: Small company , ability to make a big impact , learn a lot , and take charge of features / bug fixes. I generally liked all the people i worked with , especially the other engineers , but everyone else was hard working and cared about the mission. I don’t have a lot bad to say about the company . WLB was excellent. If you’re an early career engineer that wants to work on a mature product that still has a lot of feature work available, start here

reviews.cons: Consistently re-organizing and re-structuring; loyalty not rewarded; current CEO (Puneet Singh) and other leadership failed to push the envelope, innovate, retain customers, or derive any profit; strong decline in company culture; lack of/minimal 401K matching
reviews.pros: Great work-life balance; good health insurance coverage; excellent mental health resources

reviews.advice: There isn’t any advice the management team hasn’t heard, acknowledged and IGNORED. Its completely pointless to bring anything up because it’s routinely ignored or turned around and blamed on Care Navigation.
reviews.cons:
9/2022 UPDATE: Quartet is now taking away our unlimited PTO and our salaried positions. They are moving all of the Care Navigation/ Customer Support Staff team to hourly positions. They have given us 9 days notice and we will go without full pay while they do this. Quartet Health is the WORST company I have ever worked for. They lie, make up fake laws and only pay or reward upper management. THEY DO NOT CARE ABOUT MENTAL HEALTH AT ALL. 


They continue to advertise “unlimited pto”. However this just isn’t true. If you’re a manager or above then yes, have at it. If you’re on the Care Navigation team or the Customer Support Staff who answer phones they will not give you time off. 
They count literally everyday you are off and have a point system for those who they deem unworthy to use their “unlimited pto”. It’s now the WORST Pto plan I’ve had in 20 years in health care. 

They have also taken our 15 holidays a year and reduced it to 6. Which is well below the National average for holidays allowed per year. 

The management staff have absolutely no idea how difficult the roles are speaking to the patients on a daily basis. The burn out rate is very high due to their unrealistic metrics. Also- most patients are not cared for simply because they have the “wrong” insurance and Quartet doesn’t get paid. This place is a complete waste of time for most patients and employees. If you want to feel like the sludge at the bottom of a pond, join Quartet!
reviews.pros: The pros are pretty simple, you work from home. Which in all honesty isn’t such a pro anymore with so many companies offering this. That’s the only pro.
reviews.summary: Quartet Health; the mental health company that cares NOTHING about mental health!

reviews.advice: If a mistake is made, don't assume the worst and inquire to the person you are accusing instead of blindsiding them with punishment.
reviews.cons: Management lacks care for their employees and they use you when they need you but when you are no longer needed, say goodbye to job security. They make false promises and will blindside you with "transitions" by making decisions about YOUR job and its status behind your back. Not to mention, they lack genuine care for their patients unless they are contracted. Extremely money driven yet refuse to give raises despite increase cost of living. Continue to remove benefits such as unlimited PTO. Did I mention that you are never guaranteed time off even if you request it? Overall, as others have said, this company is going down. They have lost their transparency and specialty, becoming a corporate business driven outlook who does not care about their workers.
reviews.pros: The coworkers are extremely kind and willing to answer any questions you have, will help get you on your feet and truly care for you (unlike management/ those in higher level positions)
reviews.summary: Lack Of Care For Employees, Blindsiding Managers

reviews.cons: Everything. Quite possibly the WORST COMPANY in the health tech space and the worst company I’ve ever worked for. Unexpected lay offs. No explanation. Not a care in the world. Their crappy reviews were even brought up to management and they just stated that they were received from disgruntled employees. Yeah… okay. Do not work for this company. Horrid. Just absolutely horrid.
reviews.pros: Coworkers-not including management (that’s a given, I know)

reviews.cons: Leadership seems reactionary and failure to commit to a single business strategy has led to several rounds of layoffs.
reviews.pros: Great employees, admirable mission. The people I worked with were all wonderful and thoughtful.

reviews.cons: Everything about working there, the leadership, the pay.
reviews.pros: NONE, the company is a failure

Not you, not the patients, nothing else. Benefits used to be great and got worse over time. I’m actually not even sure how this company is still afloat given a lack of proper execution amid a great vision.

They just went through a second round of layoffs in the two years I've been at the company, meaning things have just been getting worst. Leadership does not care about employees or company culture. This is not a mission driven company any more, they DO NOT even care or prioritize their own employees mental health so please tell me how the heck would they be able to care about other's mental health ? This place is a dumpster fire and it's truly sad. I'd stay away as you may end up unemployed in a short amount of time given the state of the business.

reviews.advice: It’s truly unfortunate that Quartet is going downhill. Loss of salaries and benefits overnight with no warning, lack of transparency from the top down, and no accountability for the impact of layoffs. Many gave clear feedback during the last round of layoffs, which was completely disregarded by leadership yet again. The company does not value our efforts to make it easier for patients to connect to care. They are just focused on making money at this point, and it’s disappointing to see them cut corners to try to accomplish this. Truly unfortunate.
reviews.cons: -Limited to no opportunities for growth and development -Lack of transparency from leadership (even when they say that this is something they are working on) -Complete shift of company priorities to care delivery with no phase out plan for care connections -Regular abrupt layoffs
reviews.pros: -Remote work -Coworkers (incredible talent here) -Opportunity to directly improve outcomes for some patients

reviews.cons: limited opportunity for professional growth
reviews.pros: it has a chill work environment

reviews.advice: Grow up. Listen to your employees. Let them know that they’re heard. Listen to your employees. Care about your employees. Listen to your employees.
reviews.cons: This company is inevitably sinking and no one wants to admit it. The management of the care navigation team is absolutely horrible. The managers have one way meetings and don’t allow care navigators or care support specialists to have voices. The team members are not allowed to ask questions during meetings and are told that if they do have questions to please go to their managers in their one-on-one meetings in private. Meanwhile, all of the Care navigation members talk crap about the managers in private slack groups. The morale of the team is incredibly low, the turnover rate is extremely high, and the managers “have no idea why.” When I started with quartet, the benefits were amazing and the morale of the team was high. But, gradually, the benefits have been taken away from the care navigation team and the work life balance absolutely sucks. Oh, but don’t worry, Care navigation managers get to keep their unlimited PTO, salaried wages, and great benefits. It’s in anyone and everyone’s best interest to avoid this sinking ship of a company. They have a great mission but they do an absolutely horrible job of executing it to patients in need of mental health services. Also, the cost of living has gone up and there’s been an increase in job responsibilities for the care navigation team, yet no increase in salary. If you’re looking for a job, look elsewhere. Trust me.
reviews.pros: My coworkers and remote job.

reviews.advice: It doesn’t matter. They don’t care. They’re probably trying to save even their own jobs! That’s how downhill it’s going.
reviews.cons: Here we go again, another round of unexpected lay offs. This company does not care about patients let alone employees. It’s all about money because they know they are going downhill. The CEOs, upper management and HR completely blindsided everyone else. The way they treated us when they did the lay offs last week was unbelievable, we weren’t given the opportunity to even say goodbye to co-workers who we’ve worked with for years! I truly feel like this company will no longer be around in a year. They are running out of money. Do yourself a favor and run far away from this place.
reviews.pros: Remote. Paid Holidays. Friendly Co-workers.

By the time she is due she won’t even be covered under health insurance anymore! I wonder how management would feel if they were in her shoes. Heartless and hypocritical are the only words I have for this company and everyone sitting in management. This is NOT the Quartet it used to be. The vision is blurred, most of the talent has left or been laid off and they do not care about patients who are not contracted with insurances Quartet makes money off of.

In a single bite it comes down to no accountability for business failures, inappropriate workplace behavior, and the complete inability to accept feedback water falling all the way from the top. Let's break this down for the palate, shall we?

Look, accountability is difficult for the ego. You have to chew through and acknowledge the mistake, the oversight, the lack of research, the lack of innovation, the repeating of mistakes and failed initiatives, the willful neglect of user feedback, the pushing out of subject matter experts, the nepotism, the rapid career acceleration of friends over qualified candidates, the lack of communication, the close door decision making that lead to layoffs and a company reorg that had people taken from roles they were exceedingly well qualified for and putting them into ones that were in totally different fields, the lack meaningful feedback loops, the redefining of KPIs every quartet to spin a success story, the...oh...yeah there is a lot to chew through here. 

Hmmm, I guess we can just say that accountability starts at the top and in my 5 years I saw its presence dwindle into non-existence. Don't worry though, they'll send out a survey to learn more about why surveys don't lead to impactful changes.

The inappropriate behavior is hard to break down here, so I'll simply say that I took my fiancée to one work event, never again. Need to say more? No I do not.

Feedback is more a confirmation bias loop and if you're not part of the inner circle you will be stone walled from any meaningful platform to share concerns and it'll stunt your career progress. At Quartet who you know matters more than performance or competence.

There's a lot more complexity to the soup, huh? I hope by now you've spat it out, complained to the waiter, asked to see the manager, and know with conviction this ain't the place to dine. You can read from other reviewers, but be warned the current staff like to write their own and claim they have world famous matzoballs. I am not sure the health department would even consider it human food....and do you really want to find out for yourself when this market is exploding with new health tech companies and there are several, attractive competitors to consider?
reviews.pros:
Quartet is a weird soup. 

You may be exposed to many career pathways and find nuggets of insight about the healthcare ecosystem and tech. You can nibble into some great skill development areas and have freedom to laterally change teams, if you have a supportive manager. However, this will be marred by dysfunctional processes, broken departments, defeated colleagues, an incoherent and always changing business strategy, and an inner circle that makes life miserable for everyone in their wake. 

Everything you could learn at Quartet can be found in "The Hard Thing About Hard Things" or "Why the Mighty Fall". Go to your local book store and check out books on failed leadership, iteration, innovation, and accountability. You'll come out learning everything you would have gleaned here while enjoying life at a functional start-up building your professional equity in a meaningful way.

Don't get swayed by the seasoning of "this is a difficult problem we're trying to solve" or the spices of "we've learned a lot along the way". As a five year vet at Quartet what they learned was how to reuse the same talk track after every failure. 

The mission meant the world to me as someone who lost loved ones to suicide, addiction, and domestic violence. Quartet will exploit your goodwill and dedication to pawn a quick buck on a doomed to fail business model. Trust me, this soup is served to burn your mouth and make you numb to sensation so you just trust them when they say "This is good soup". It ain't!

reviews.advice: Change doesn't happen in a day, but stay focused on what we commit to (to our team and our clients). Changing strategy is not always translated well to people's day to day, or thought through at that level. I agree with some of the other reviews that more questions should be asked of those actually doing the work prior to major changes.
reviews.cons:
- Like others said, Quartet recently hired groups of people from Aspire and similar places. I agree we should expand our horizons to keep adding diverse talent
-The 401(k) match should be increased
- Some of the leaders (high level, the managers are usually great) are better than others. My advice is to ask thoughtful questions about your executive leadership when interviewing here

None of these are dealbreakers for me, so I'm keeping my rating at 5 stars, but realistically it's probably between 4-5 stars based on some of the cons.
reviews.pros:
Quartet is one of many players in the health tech-enabled space. It's not for everyone, but I think it has a lot going for it. My experience at Quartet has had quite a few "pros."

- Smart and kind people across the board. Feeling like you can reach out to anyone with a question is paid lip service at other companies, but it's real here
- Inspiring mission, evolving strategy. Shifting strategy is frustrating, but the new strategy is objectively clearer, and I understand how we plan to make money with the new changes. Before...not so much 
- New, interesting challenges. This probably isn't true for every role or team, but I think my day-to-day is rich with new experiences
- I'm not patient-facing, so my view is limited, but I think we highlight our patient wins well and often. I love hearing about the indirect impact of my work on someone getting the care they need

I feel like you could throw a stone and hit 10 other companies "similar" to Quartet (Cerebral, Ginger, Alma, etc). I like what we're doing differently, the people, and my work, so it's a great match for me. Maybe it's not for you, but I'd take other reviews with a grain of salt and find out for yourself.
reviews.summary: Lots of change, but lots of positives as well

reviews.advice:
It's a classic case of not taking care of your employees. Leadership has no idea what employees do and how they speak/assist patients all day every day. It is incredibly taxing work. 

Employees talk amongst themselves and morale is incredibly low. Never worked at a place with such low morale as here. They talk about quitting, burnout, and dread of coming into work every day. 

Implement real changes like higher salaries, less micro management, better work life balance, and adjusted metrics. 

The work Quartet does is important but the culture and environment isn't helpful to the mission. 

Bad employee experience = bad patient experience. Quite obvious but this seems like a concept that hasn't yet been realized by leadership.
reviews.cons:
- There's a lot of micro management because they are so focused on metrics. It creates extreme burnout, stress, and overall just a horrible time while at work. The metrics goals are not sustainable and unreachable. 

- The salary is laughable. For the type and amount of work that is required, they do not pay well. People make a lot more doing a lot less elsewhere. 

-The bonuses are also laughable. Almost impossible to attain because it's based on unrealistic goals. You have to work like a robot and still you may not reach them. Yet they wonder why no one's metrics are met. 

- Turnover rate is incredibly high. Management changes, poorly thought out metrics and workflows, and a lot of the jobs themselves are horrible to do. Always understaffed due to high turnover. 

- Out of Touch Leadership: Great lip service but that's about it. Employees are miserable yet leadership thinks everything is great. For Employee Appreciation Day, let's just say their show of appreciation became a running joke in the company.
reviews.pros:
Pros:
The coworkers are some of the nicest, well intentioned, true advocates of mental health you'll ever meet. 

Benefits are okay. Health plans are decent and they reimburse a lot of expenses. 

Pretty much it.
reviews.summary: Nice People but Horrible Expectations and Pay

reviews.cons: Quartet is struggling to find product market fit. Some of its products are useful and impactful , some are a solution in search of a problem.
reviews.pros: Small company , ability to make a big impact , learn a lot , and take charge of features / bug fixes. I generally liked all the people i worked with , especially the other engineers , but everyone else was hard working and cared about the mission. I don’t have a lot bad to say about the company . WLB was excellent. If you’re an early career engineer that wants to work on a mature product that still has a lot of feature work available, start here

reviews.advice: None! Continue working to promote transparency and a culture of One Team!
reviews.cons: None that I'm aware of at this time.
reviews.pros:
The company is very mission driven and you can feel that in every interaction. 
One of our core values is that we are One Team and you can truly feel that when working cross-functionally. 
Leadership has done an amazing job at taking previous feedback and implementing it to make them more available to employees by creating monthly office hours where employees can learn about what the strategy for that department looks like. 

In my 10+ years in the corporate world I can truly say that Quartet has been the best company I've ever worked for. I have never felt more valued in a corporate setting as I do at Quartet.

reviews.advice: There isn’t any advice the management team hasn’t heard, acknowledged and IGNORED. Its completely pointless to bring anything up because it’s routinely ignored or turned around and blamed on Care Navigation.
reviews.cons:
9/2022 UPDATE: Quartet is now taking away our unlimited PTO and our salaried positions. They are moving all of the Care Navigation/ Customer Support Staff team to hourly positions. They have given us 9 days notice and we will go without full pay while they do this. Quartet Health is the WORST company I have ever worked for. They lie, make up fake laws and only pay or reward upper management. THEY DO NOT CARE ABOUT MENTAL HEALTH AT ALL. 


They continue to advertise “unlimited pto”. However this just isn’t true. If you’re a manager or above then yes, have at it. If you’re on the Care Navigation team or the Customer Support Staff who answer phones they will not give you time off. 
They count literally everyday you are off and have a point system for those who they deem unworthy to use their “unlimited pto”. It’s now the WORST Pto plan I’ve had in 20 years in health care. 

They have also taken our 15 holidays a year and reduced it to 6. Which is well below the National average for holidays allowed per year. 

The management staff have absolutely no idea how difficult the roles are speaking to the patients on a daily basis. The burn out rate is very high due to their unrealistic metrics. Also- most patients are not cared for simply because they have the “wrong” insurance and Quartet doesn’t get paid. This place is a complete waste of time for most patients and employees. If you want to feel like the sludge at the bottom of a pond, join Quartet!
reviews.pros: The pros are pretty simple, you work from home. Which in all honesty isn’t such a pro anymore with so many companies offering this. That’s the only pro.
reviews.summary: Quartet Health; the mental health company that cares NOTHING about mental health!

reviews.advice: Treat your employees like you use to. Most of the great talent has left or is going to leave. Why be the Walmart of digital health when you could be Target.
reviews.cons: In my time with the company they have slowly chipped away at the benefits package they offered. When I first started unlimited PTO was standard along with other great benefits. We recently have been told that we will no longer be receiving such a benefit. Along with that they have changed us from a salaried position to hourly. It is in my opinion that Quartet no longer cares about the employees who do the brunt of the work and are more about the bottom line. I’d think twice before apply here.

reviews.advice: Grow up. Listen to your employees. Let them know that they’re heard. Listen to your employees. Care about your employees. Listen to your employees.
reviews.cons: This company is inevitably sinking and no one wants to admit it. The management of the care navigation team is absolutely horrible. The managers have one way meetings and don’t allow care navigators or care support specialists to have voices. The team members are not allowed to ask questions during meetings and are told that if they do have questions to please go to their managers in their one-on-one meetings in private. Meanwhile, all of the Care navigation members talk crap about the managers in private slack groups. The morale of the team is incredibly low, the turnover rate is extremely high, and the managers “have no idea why.” When I started with quartet, the benefits were amazing and the morale of the team was high. But, gradually, the benefits have been taken away from the care navigation team and the work life balance absolutely sucks. Oh, but don’t worry, Care navigation managers get to keep their unlimited PTO, salaried wages, and great benefits. It’s in anyone and everyone’s best interest to avoid this sinking ship of a company. They have a great mission but they do an absolutely horrible job of executing it to patients in need of mental health services. Also, the cost of living has gone up and there’s been an increase in job responsibilities for the care navigation team, yet no increase in salary. If you’re looking for a job, look elsewhere. Trust me.

# Employee Sentiments

## Reasons Employees Like Working at Quartet Health

### Positive Work Environment
- "Smart and kind people across the board. Feeling like you can reach out to anyone with a question is paid lip service at other companies, but it's real here." [(Anonymous, Glassdoor, 2022-04-27)](https://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Quartet-Health-RVW63362467.htm)
- "The company is very mission driven and you can feel that in every interaction." [(Anonymous, Glassdoor, 2022-08-08)](https://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Quartet-Health-RVW67678095.htm)
- "The vast majority of people working at Quartet Health are friendly, kind, and extremely hard-working." [(Assistance (Undisclosed), Glassdoor, 2024-09-04)](https://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Quartet-Health-RVW90704306.htm)

### Opportunities for Growth
- "Great opportunity for growth." [(Anonymous, Glassdoor, 2023-05-23)](https://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Quartet-Health-RVW76722464.htm)
- "A lot of smart and dedicated people work here... the work is interesting, as there are multiple product lines and plenty of analytically interesting challenges." [(Senior Manager, Glassdoor, 2024-06-20)](https://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Quartet-Health-RVW88441725.htm)

### Flexibility and Work-Life Balance
- "Work/life balance can be really positive because expectations are low." [(Operations, Glassdoor, 2022-04-11)](https://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Quartet-Health-RVW62627815.htm)
- "The business is fully remote, and work-life balance is good." [(Senior Manager, Glassdoor, 2024-06-20)](https://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Quartet-Health-RVW88441725.htm)

## Reasons Employees Dislike Working at Quartet Health

### Poor Leadership and Management
- "Leadership is misogynistic, NO DEI initiatives... it's all a facade." [(Anonymous, Glassdoor, 2022-01-27)](https://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Quartet-Health-RVW58672277.htm)
- "Management lacks care for their employees and they use you when they need you but when you are no longer needed, say goodbye to job security." [(Anonymous, Glassdoor, 2023-02-02)](https://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Quartet-Health-RVW73258359.htm)

### High Turnover and Job Insecurity
- "Turnover rate is incredibly high... management changes, poorly thought out metrics and workflows." [(Anonymous, Glassdoor, 2022-06-23)](https://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Quartet-Health-RVW65911950.htm)
- "This company is inevitably sinking and no one wants to admit it." [(Care Navigation, Glassdoor, 2023-01-15)](https://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Quartet-Health-RVW72645233.htm)
